Hovey — 4
Interestingly enough, one of the biggest fights with his own party cane when Scelba
named Martino minister of education* The Liberals demanded this position as rart of
their price for participating in the Scelba government* The Christian Democrats had
maintained a tight grip on the education ministry during most of the postwar years, and
many observers felt they would never give it up. And they were able to put one of their
own in this job once again when Scelba moved Martino to the foreign office last fall.
Anyhow, Scelba eventually reconstituted the democratic coalition. His is a cabinet
of Christian Democrats, Social Democrats and Liberals, with the Republicans supporting,
but not actually participating. And this government now has lasted well over a year.
How much longer it will last is anybody1 s guess. Martino's Liberal party recently
threatened a crisis over an issue of farm tenant contracts. The Republicans are be¬
coming restless. In any event, the Scelba government is bound by constitutional pro¬
vision to resign formally after the election of a new president of the republic next
month.
How well Scelba has done in his year as premier is also a live debating topic. In
terms of actual legislation to carry out his program, he has not compiled an impressive
record. But he did bring off the return of Trieste to Italy, He and Martino will go to
Washington with the ratification of the European Union treaty in their pockets. He has
given stability to a country that seemed to be faltering and stumbling toward some kind
of totalitarianism.
If democratic government survives and flourishes in Italy, Scelba will surely get
considerable credit. He was the man who never at any time lost faith in it. H© was the
Christian Democratic leader who always vigorously opposed a turn to the right and a bid
for support of the Monarchists. He has opposed with equal vigor any decisive turn to
the left, and a bid for the support of Pietro Nenni's Socialist party, v/hich nearly
always follows the Communist line.
If democratic government eventually gives way in Italy, the crackup of the Christian
Democrat-Social Democrat-Liberal-Republican coalition could be the first signal. And it
could turn out that Scelba headed the last serious attempt to make such a democratic
coalition government work.
As I said earlier, the political fortune of Gaetano Martino, too, would seem to be
tied to success for this democratic coalition idea which he has strongly supported. But
perhaps this is not quite so certain as it is in the case of Mario Scelba. For Martino
has made enough of an impression on the country to figure prominently in speculation
about the new president of the republic, to be elected very shortly.
At this moment, Martino's chances of succeeding President Einaudi in May would seem
to be of the "daikhorse" variety. Some Italians feel that at 54 he is too young, Some
feel he has advanced a little too rapidly. But given an early deadlock in the presiden¬
tial assembly, Martino might make it. He then would have to place himself above the
political battle.
These, then, are the two men from Sicily — Mario Scelba and Gaetano Martino — who
will be visiting fashington about the time you hear this broadcast* two Italian states¬
men different from one another in many respects but agteed in their stand for middle
road democracy at home, and a pro-western, European unity policy abroad.
Graham Hovey reporting. This Letter from Italy was recorded in Rome studios of
